column2: CHAPTER V
column3: CHAPTER five

column2: I do not know what your opinion may be, Mrs. Weston, said Mr. Knightley, "of this great intimacy between Emma and Harriet Smith, but I think it a bad thing."
column3: I do not know what your opinion may be, mrs Weston, said mr Knightley, "of this great intimacy between Emma and Harriet Smith, but I think it a bad thing."

column2: A bad thing!	A bad thing!
column3: true

column2: Do you really think it a bad thing?--why so?"
column3: Do you really think it a bad thing?--why so?"

column2: I think they will neither of them do the other any good.
column3: I think they will neither of them do the other any good.

column2: You surprize me!	You surprize me!
column3: true

column2: Emma must do Harriet good: and by supplying her with a new object of interest, Harriet may be said to do Emma good.
column3: Emma must do Harriet good: and by supplying her with a new object of interest, Harriet may be said to do Emma good.

column2: I have been seeing their intimacy with the greatest pleasure.
column3: I have been seeing their intimacy with the greatest pleasure.

column2: How very differently we feel!--Not think they will do each other any good!
column3: How very differently we feel!--Not think they will do each other any good!

column2: This will certainly be the beginning of one of our quarrels about Emma, Mr. Knightley."
column3: This will certainly be the beginning of one of our quarrels about Emma, mr Knightley."

column2: Perhaps you think I am come on purpose to quarrel with you, knowing Weston to be out, and that you must still fight your own battle.
column3: Perhaps you think I am come on purpose to quarrel with you, knowing Weston to be out, and that you must still fight your own battle.

column2: Mr. Weston would undoubtedly support me, if he were here, for he thinks exactly as I do on the subject.	mr Weston would undoubtedly support me, if he were here, for he thinks exactly as I do on the subject.
column3: true

column2: We were speaking of it only yesterday, and agreeing how fortunate it was for Emma, that there should be such a girl in Highbury for her to associate with.
column3: We were speaking of it only yesterday, and agreeing how fortunate it was for Emma, that there should be such a girl in Highbury for her to associate with.

column2: Mr. Knightley, I shall not allow you to be a fair judge in this case.
column3: mr Knightley, I shall not allow you to be a fair judge in this case.

column2: You are so much used to live alone, that you do not know the value of a companion; and, perhaps no man can be a good judge of the comfort a woman feels in the society of one of her own sex, after being used to it all her life.
column3: You are so much used to live alone, that you do not know the value of a companion; and, perhaps no man can be a good judge of the comfort a woman feels in the society of one of her own sex, after being used to it all her life.

column2: I can imagine your objection to Harriet Smith.
column3: I can imagine your objection to Harriet Smith.

column2: She is not the superior young woman which Emma's friend ought to be.
column3: She is not the superior young woman which Emma's friend ought to be.

column2: But on the other hand, as Emma wants to see her better informed, it will be an inducement to her to read more herself.
column3: But on the other hand, as Emma wants to see her better informed, it will be an inducement to her to read more herself.

column2: They will read together.
column3: They will read together.

column2: She means it, I know."
column3: She means it, I know."

column2: Emma has been meaning to read more ever since she was twelve years old. I have seen a great many lists of her drawing-up at various times of books that she meant to read regularly through--and very good lists they were--very well chosen, and very neatly arranged--sometimes alphabetically, and sometimes by some other rule.	Emma has been meaning to read more ever since she was twelve years old. I have seen a great many lists of her drawing up at various times of books that she meant to read regularly through-and very good lists they were-very well chosen, and very neatly arranged-sometimes alphabetically, and sometimes by some other rule.
column3: true

column2: The list she drew up when only fourteen--I remember thinking it did her judgment so much credit, that I preserved it some time; and I dare say she may have made out a very good list now.
column3: The list she drew up when only fourteen-I remember thinking it did her judgment so much credit, that I preserved it some time; and I dare say she may have made out a very good list now.

column2: But I have done with expecting any course of steady reading from Emma.
column3: But I have done with expecting any course of steady reading from Emma.

column2: She will never submit to any thing requiring industry and patience, and a subjection of the fancy to the understanding.
column3: She will never submit to any thing requiring industry and patience, and a subjection of the fancy to the understanding.

column2: Where Miss Taylor failed to stimulate, I may safely affirm that Harriet Smith will do nothing.--You never could persuade her to read half so much as you wished.--You know you could not."
column3: Where Miss Taylor failed to stimulate, I may safely affirm that Harriet Smith will do nothing.--You never could persuade her to read half so much as you wished.--You know you could not."

column2: I dare say, replied Mrs. Weston, smiling, "that I thought so _then_;--but since we have parted, I can never remember Emma's omitting to do any thing I wished."
column3: I dare say, replied mrs Weston, smiling, "that I thought so underscore then underscore;--but since we have parted, I can never remember Emma's omitting to do any thing I wished."

column2: There is hardly any desiring to refresh such a memory as _that_,--said Mr. Knightley, feelingly; and for a moment or two he had done.
column3: There is hardly any desiring to refresh such a memory as underscore that underscore,--said mr Knightley, feelingly; and for a moment or two he had done.

column2: But I, he soon added, "who have had no such charm thrown over my senses, must still see, hear, and remember.
column3: But I, he soon added, "who have had no such charm thrown over my senses, must still see, hear, and remember.

column2: Emma is spoiled by being the cleverest of her family.
column3: Emma is spoiled by being the cleverest of her family.

column2: At ten years old, she had the misfortune of being able to answer questions which puzzled her sister at seventeen.
column3: At ten years old, she had the misfortune of being able to answer questions which puzzled her sister at seventeen.

column2: She was always quick and assured: Isabella slow and diffident.
column3: She was always quick and assured: Isabella slow and diffident.

column2: And ever since she was twelve, Emma has been mistress of the house and of you all.
column3: And ever since she was twelve, Emma has been mistress of the house and of you all.

column2: In her mother she lost the only person able to cope with her.
column3: In her mother she lost the only person able to cope with her.

column2: She inherits her mother's talents, and must have been under subjection to her."
column3: She inherits her mother's talents, and must have been under subjection to her."

column2: I should have been sorry, Mr. Knightley, to be dependent on _your_ recommendation, had I quitted Mr. Woodhouse's family and wanted another situation; I do not think you would have spoken a good word for me to any body.	I should have been sorry, mr Knightley, to be dependent on underscore your underscore recommendation, had I quitted mr Woodhouse's family and wanted another situation; I do not think you would have spoken a good word for me to any body.
column3: false

column2: I am sure you always thought me unfit for the office I held."
column3: I am sure you always thought me unfit for the office I held."

column2: Yes, said he, smiling.
column3: Yes, said he, smiling.

column2: You are better placed _here_; very fit for a wife, but not at all for a governess.	You are better placed underscore here underscore; very fit for a wife, but not at all for a governess.
column3: false

column2: But you were preparing yourself to be an excellent wife all the time you were at Hartfield.
column3: But you were preparing yourself to be an excellent wife all the time you were at Hartfield.

column2: You might not give Emma such a complete education as your powers would seem to promise; but you were receiving a very good education from _her_, on the very material matrimonial point of submitting your own will, and doing as you were bid; and if Weston had asked me to recommend him a wife, I should certainly have named Miss Taylor."
column3: You might not give Emma such a complete education as your powers would seem to promise; but you were receiving a very good education from underscore her underscore, on the very material matrimonial point of submitting your own will, and doing as you were bid; and if Weston had asked me to recommend him a wife, I should certainly have named Miss Taylor."

column2: Thank you.	Thank you.
column3: true

column2: There will be very little merit in making a good wife to such a man as Mr. Weston."
column3: There will be very little merit in making a good wife to such a man as mr Weston."

column2: Why, to own the truth, I am afraid you are rather thrown away, and that with every disposition to bear, there will be nothing to be borne.	Why, to own the truth, I am afraid you are rather thrown away, and that with every disposition to bear, there will be nothing to be borne.
column3: true

column2: We will not despair, however.
column3: We will not despair, however.

column2: Weston may grow cross from the wantonness of comfort, or his son may plague him."
column3: Weston may grow cross from the wantonness of comfort, or his son may plague him."

column2: I hope not _that_.--It is not likely.	I hope not underscore that underscore.--It is not likely.
column3: false

column2: No, Mr. Knightley, do not foretell vexation from that quarter."
column3: No, mr Knightley, do not foretell vexation from that quarter."

column2: Not I, indeed.	Not I, indeed.
column3: true

column2: I only name possibilities.
column3: I only name possibilities.

column2: I do not pretend to Emma's genius for foretelling and guessing.
column3: I do not pretend to Emma's genius for foretelling and guessing.

column2: I hope, with all my heart, the young man may be a Weston in merit, and a Churchill in fortune.--But Harriet Smith--I have not half done about Harriet Smith.
column3: I hope, with all my heart, the young man may be a Weston in merit, and a Churchill in fortune.--But Harriet Smith-I have not half done about Harriet Smith.

column2: I think her the very worst sort of companion that Emma could possibly have.
column3: I think her the very worst sort of companion that Emma could possibly have.

column2: She knows nothing herself, and looks upon Emma as knowing every thing.
column3: She knows nothing herself, and looks upon Emma as knowing every thing.

column2: She is a flatterer in all her ways; and so much the worse, because undesigned. Her ignorance is hourly flattery.
column3: She is a flatterer in all her ways; and so much the worse, because undesigned. Her ignorance is hourly flattery.

column2: How can Emma imagine she has any thing to learn herself, while Harriet is presenting such a delightful inferiority?
column3: How can Emma imagine she has any thing to learn herself, while Harriet is presenting such a delightful inferiority?

column2: And as for Harriet, I will venture to say that _she_ cannot gain by the acquaintance.
column3: And as for Harriet, I will venture to say that underscore she underscore cannot gain by the acquaintance.

column2: Hartfield will only put her out of conceit with all the other places she belongs to.
column3: Hartfield will only put her out of conceit with all the other places she belongs to.

column2: She will grow just refined enough to be uncomfortable with those among whom birth and circumstances have placed her home.
column3: She will grow just refined enough to be uncomfortable with those among whom birth and circumstances have placed her home.

column2: I am much mistaken if Emma's doctrines give any strength of mind, or tend at all to make a girl adapt herself rationally to the varieties of her situation in life.--They only give a little polish."
column3: I am much mistaken if Emma's doctrines give any strength of mind, or tend at all to make a girl adapt herself rationally to the varieties of her situation in life.--They only give a little polish."

column2: I either depend more upon Emma's good sense than you do, or am more anxious for her present comfort; for I cannot lament the acquaintance. How well she looked last night!
column3: I either depend more upon Emma's good sense than you do, or am more anxious for her present comfort; for I cannot lament the acquaintance. How well she looked last night!

column2: Oh! you would rather talk of her person than her mind, would you?	Oh! you would rather talk of her person than her mind, would you?
column3: true

column2: Very well; I shall not attempt to deny Emma's being pretty."
column3: Very well; I shall not attempt to deny Emma's being pretty."

column2: Pretty! say beautiful rather.	Pretty! say beautiful rather.
column3: true

column2: Can you imagine any thing nearer perfect beauty than Emma altogether--face and figure?"
column3: Can you imagine any thing nearer perfect beauty than Emma altogether-face and figure?"

column2: I do not know what I could imagine, but I confess that I have seldom seen a face or figure more pleasing to me than hers.	I do not know what I could imagine, but I confess that I have seldom seen a face or figure more pleasing to me than hers.
column3: true

column2: But I am a partial old friend."
column3: But I am a partial old friend."

column2: Such an eye!--the true hazle eye--and so brilliant! regular features, open countenance, with a complexion! oh! what a bloom of full health, and such a pretty height and size; such a firm and upright figure! There is health, not merely in her bloom, but in her air, her head, her glance.	Such an eye!--the true hazle eye-and so brilliant! regular features, open countenance, with a complexion! oh! what a bloom of full health, and such a pretty height and size; such a firm and upright figure! There is health, not merely in her bloom, but in her air, her head, her glance.
column3: false

column2: One hears sometimes of a child being 'the picture of health;' now, Emma always gives me the idea of being the complete picture of grown-up health.
column3: One hears sometimes of a child being 'the picture of health;' now, Emma always gives me the idea of being the complete picture of grown up health.

column2: She is loveliness itself.
column3: She is loveliness itself.

column2: Mr. Knightley, is not she?"
column3: mr Knightley, is not she?"

column2: I have not a fault to find with her person, he replied.
column3: I have not a fault to find with her person, he replied.

column2: I think her all you describe.	I think her all you describe.
column3: true

column2: I love to look at her; and I will add this praise, that I do not think her personally vain.
column3: I love to look at her; and I will add this praise, that I do not think her personally vain.

column2: Considering how very handsome she is, she appears to be little occupied with it; her vanity lies another way.
column3: Considering how very handsome she is, she appears to be little occupied with it; her vanity lies another way.

column2: Mrs. Weston, I am not to be talked out of my dislike of Harriet Smith, or my dread of its doing them both harm."
column3: mrs Weston, I am not to be talked out of my dislike of Harriet Smith, or my dread of its doing them both harm."

column2: And I, Mr. Knightley, am equally stout in my confidence of its not doing them any harm.	And I, mr Knightley, am equally stout in my confidence of its not doing them any harm.
column3: true

column2: With all dear Emma's little faults, she is an excellent creature.
column3: With all dear Emma's little faults, she is an excellent creature.

column2: Where shall we see a better daughter, or a kinder sister, or a truer friend?
column3: Where shall we see a better daughter, or a kinder sister, or a truer friend?

column2: No, no; she has qualities which may be trusted; she will never lead any one really wrong; she will make no lasting blunder; where Emma errs once, she is in the right a hundred times."
column3: No, no; she has qualities which may be trusted; she will never lead any one really wrong; she will make no lasting blunder; where Emma errs once, she is in the right a hundred times."

column2: Very well; I will not plague you any more.	Very well; I will not plague you any more.
column3: true

column2: Emma shall be an angel, and I will keep my spleen to myself till Christmas brings John and Isabella. John loves Emma with a reasonable and therefore not a blind affection, and Isabella always thinks as he does; except when he is not quite frightened enough about the children.
column3: Emma shall be an angel, and I will keep my spleen to myself till Christmas brings john and Isabella. john loves Emma with a reasonable and therefore not a blind affection, and Isabella always thinks as he does; except when he is not quite frightened enough about the children.

column2: I am sure of having their opinions with me."
column3: I am sure of having their opinions with me."

column2: I know that you all love her really too well to be unjust or unkind; but excuse me, Mr. Knightley, if I take the liberty (I consider myself, you know, as having somewhat of the privilege of speech that Emma's mother might have had) the liberty of hinting that I do not think any possible good can arise from Harriet Smith's intimacy being made a matter of much discussion among you.	I know that you all love her really too well to be unjust or unkind; but excuse me, mr Knightley, if I take the liberty (I consider myself, you know, as having somewhat of the privilege of speech that Emma's mother might have had) the liberty of hinting that I do not think any possible good can arise from Harriet Smith's intimacy being made a matter of much discussion among you.
column3: true

column2: Pray excuse me; but supposing any little inconvenience may be apprehended from the intimacy, it cannot be expected that Emma, accountable to nobody but her father, who perfectly approves the acquaintance, should put an end to it, so long as it is a source of pleasure to herself.
column3: Pray excuse me; but supposing any little inconvenience may be apprehended from the intimacy, it cannot be expected that Emma, accountable to nobody but her father, who perfectly approves the acquaintance, should put an end to it, so long as it is a source of pleasure to herself.

column2: It has been so many years my province to give advice, that you cannot be surprized, Mr. Knightley, at this little remains of office."
column3: It has been so many years my province to give advice, that you cannot be surprized, mr Knightley, at this little remains of office."

column2: Not at all, cried he; "I am much obliged to you for it.
column3: Not at all, cried he; "I am much obliged to you for it.

column2: It is very good advice, and it shall have a better fate than your advice has often found; for it shall be attended to."
column3: It is very good advice, and it shall have a better fate than your advice has often found; for it shall be attended to."

column2: Mrs. John Knightley is easily alarmed, and might be made unhappy about her sister.
column3: mrs john Knightley is easily alarmed, and might be made unhappy about her sister.

column2: Be satisfied, said he, "I will not raise any outcry.
column3: Be satisfied, said he, "I will not raise any outcry.

column2: I will keep my ill-humour to myself.
column3: I will keep my ill humour to myself.

column2: I have a very sincere interest in Emma.
column3: I have a very sincere interest in Emma.

column2: Isabella does not seem more my sister; has never excited a greater interest; perhaps hardly so great.
column3: Isabella does not seem more my sister; has never excited a greater interest; perhaps hardly so great.

column2: There is an anxiety, a curiosity in what one feels for Emma.
column3: There is an anxiety, a curiosity in what one feels for Emma.

column2: I wonder what will become of her!"
column3: I wonder what will become of her!"

column2: So do I, said Mrs. Weston gently, "very much."
column3: So do I, said mrs Weston gently, "very much."

column2: She always declares she will never marry, which, of course, means just nothing at all.	She always declares she will never marry, which, of course, means just nothing at all.
column3: true

column2: But I have no idea that she has yet ever seen a man she cared for.
column3: But I have no idea that she has yet ever seen a man she cared for.

column2: It would not be a bad thing for her to be very much in love with a proper object.
column3: It would not be a bad thing for her to be very much in love with a proper object.

column2: I should like to see Emma in love, and in some doubt of a return; it would do her good.
column3: I should like to see Emma in love, and in some doubt of a return; it would do her good.

column2: But there is nobody hereabouts to attach her; and she goes so seldom from home."
column3: But there is nobody hereabouts to attach her; and she goes so seldom from home."

column2: There does, indeed, seem as little to tempt her to break her resolution at present, said Mrs. Weston, "as can well be; and while she is so happy at Hartfield, I cannot wish her to be forming any attachment which would be creating such difficulties on poor Mr. Woodhouse's account.
column3: There does, indeed, seem as little to tempt her to break her resolution at present, said mrs Weston, "as can well be; and while she is so happy at Hartfield, I cannot wish her to be forming any attachment which would be creating such difficulties on poor mr Woodhouse's account.

column2: I do not recommend matrimony at present to Emma, though I mean no slight to the state, I assure you."
column3: I do not recommend matrimony at present to Emma, though I mean no slight to the state, I assure you."

column2: Part of her meaning was to conceal some favourite thoughts of her own and Mr. Weston's on the subject, as much as possible.
column3: Part of her meaning was to conceal some favourite thoughts of her own and mr Weston's on the subject, as much as possible.

column2: There were wishes at Randalls respecting Emma's destiny, but it was not desirable to have them suspected; and the quiet transition which Mr. Knightley soon afterwards made to "What does Weston think of the weather; shall we have rain?" convinced her that he had nothing more to say or surmise about Hartfield.
column3: There were wishes at Randalls respecting Emma's destiny, but it was not desirable to have them suspected; and the quiet transition which mr Knightley soon afterwards made to "What does Weston think of the weather; shall we have rain?" convinced her that he had nothing more to say or surmise about Hartfield.

column2: CHAPTER VI
column3: CHAPTER six

column2: Emma could not feel a doubt of having given Harriet's fancy a proper direction and raised the gratitude of her young vanity to a very good purpose, for she found her decidedly more sensible than before of Mr. Elton's being a remarkably handsome man, with most agreeable manners; and as she had no hesitation in following up the assurance of his admiration by agreeable hints, she was soon pretty confident of creating as much liking on Harriet's side, as there could be any occasion for. She was quite convinced of Mr. Elton's being in the fairest way of falling in love, if not in love already.
column3: Emma could not feel a doubt of having given Harriet's fancy a proper direction and raised the gratitude of her young vanity to a very good purpose, for she found her decidedly more sensible than before of mr Elton's being a remarkably handsome man, with most agreeable manners; and as she had no hesitation in following up the assurance of his admiration by agreeable hints, she was soon pretty confident of creating as much liking on Harriet's side, as there could be any occasion for. She was quite convinced of mr Elton's being in the fairest way of falling in love, if not in love already.

column2: She had no scruple with regard to him.
column3: She had no scruple with regard to him.

column2: He talked of Harriet, and praised her so warmly, that she could not suppose any thing wanting which a little time would not add.
column3: He talked of Harriet, and praised her so warmly, that she could not suppose any thing wanting which a little time would not add.

column2: His perception of the striking improvement of Harriet's manner, since her introduction at Hartfield, was not one of the least agreeable proofs of his growing attachment.
column3: His perception of the striking improvement of Harriet's manner, since her introduction at Hartfield, was not one of the least agreeable proofs of his growing attachment.
